Hadush Kebatu, Epping sex offender, deported to Ethiopia, Home Office confirms

2025-10-29 · properly-fucked

Hadush Kebatu, an Ethiopian national, has been deported to Ethiopia after being wrongly released from a UK prison. His removal followed a two-day search subsequent to his erroneous discharge from HMP Chelmsford.

The recent logistical exercise involving Mr. Hadush Kebatu concluded with his successful transfer to Ethiopia, marking the completion of an administrative sequence that began with an unexpected deviation. Earlier in the week, Mr. Kebatu's scheduled transition from HMP Chelmsford to an immigration detention facility experienced an unscheduled modification, resulting in his temporary re-entry into the general population. This particular procedural anomaly necessitated a brief, albeit focused, re-engagement effort by law enforcement personnel to re-establish his location. Such occurrences underscore the dynamic nature of custodial transitions within the existing framework.

Following a period of two days where Mr. Kebatu was not precisely where he was intended to be, a coordinated effort led to his re-apprehension in London. The Home Secretary, Ms. Shabana Mahmood, subsequently acknowledged the initial 'blunder,' a term that efficiently encapsulates the unintended outcome of the process. She further articulated appreciation for the swift action of the police and the observational capacities of the public. This collective vigilance played a role in ensuring that the established itinerary for Mr. Kebatu could resume its intended course.

Mr. Kebatu was then placed upon a flight, arriving in Ethiopia, thereby completing the final stage of his mandated removal from the UK. The Home Secretary noted that this outcome renders 'our streets safer,' a declaration that offers a clear metric for the success of such operations. The stated objective, 'If you come to this country and commit crimes, we will remove you,' serves as a concise summary of the operational philosophy. This incident, therefore, provides a tangible demonstration of the system's capacity to recalibrate following an initial, unscheduled adjustment.
